Not that anyone here cares to read the Creationist slant on soft tissue found in dinosaurs...but here it is....notice how they, as well, are calling for carbon 14 dating on them:
 
 http://creationsafaris.com/crev200503.htm
 
 This appears to falsify, in one dramatic swoop, the claim that dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago. Why don't the scientists admit it? It's uncanny how all the reports treat the 70 million figure like an unquestionable fact, despite the clear implications of this discovery. Notice how the BBC treats the date like dogma: 
 
 In the hotly contested field of dino research, the work will be greeted with acclaim and disbelief in equal measure.
 What seems certain is that some fairly remarkable conditions must [sic] have existed at the Montana site where the T. rex died, 68 million years ago. 
 
 Seems certain to whom? Not to people with their heads screwed on, who have refused to take the oath of loyalty to the Darwin Party, or signed on to the Committee to Protect the Geologic Column at All Costs. We'll have to see if the NCSE censors this paper, preventing teachers from showing it to their students, to protect their sensitive minds from anxiety when they compare it with their textbooks.
 
 Making the excuse that the process of fossilization is not well understood is pitiful, and imagining these Montana sediments escaping millions of years of mountain uplift, erosion and climate change is a big stretch. Though airtight amber sometimes preserves all the details of an insect, it is incredibly improbable that soft, pliable tissues from a large dinosaur could be preserved in a sedimentary matrix for 10,000 years, let alone 70 million. Somebody ought to press the point. The BBC explains why: "Normally when an animal dies, worms and bugs will quickly eat up anything that is soft. Then, as the remaining bone material gets buried deeper and deeper in the mud, it gets heated, crushed and replaced by minerals, turning it to stone." Schweitzer said in the NG coverage that "our theories of how fossils are preserved don't allow for this [soft-tissue preservation]." The pathetic response of some scientists, upon hearing this announcement, is that the soft tissue recovery might help them construct better phylogenetic trees. They seem oblivious to the fact that the data threaten to cut off the long-age limb they are sitting on.
 
 Here is an opportunity for young-earth creationists to make a strong case. It's easier to prove an upper limit than a lower limit: e.g., that under the best of conditions, cells or blood vessels could not be older than a maximum number of years based on lab observations. No reader could claim by observation that they could last millions of years. Thus, the young-age position is more conservative, cautious and empirically based.  Someone should also apply carbon dating to the tissues and see if any C-14 is present. It would be below the detection threshold if the bone is as old as claimed. Watch the efforts to find out if DNA is still present, which "cannot survive that long" according to Derek Briggs in the News@Nature article. These are two predictions that can be tested.
 
 This find is making it easier to believe that dinosaurs actually lived in relatively recent times and were buried quickly by a watery catastrophe just as a Biblical chronology indicates. Dramatic as this announcement is, it is not the first. Creationists have followed up on soft-tissue claims for years. In 1994, Buddy Davis and a team endured danger and hardship recovering hadrosaur bones in Alaska that contained unfossilized tissue; their story is published in The Great Alaskan Dinosaur Adventure. Then there was the announcement in all the papers 10/15/2002 about mummified dinosaur remains. Even more remarkable was the BBC News story about mummified soft parts found in a crustacean claimed to be 511 million years old - over seven times older than the dinosaurs on the evolutionary scale (see 07/20/2001 entry). That such announcements are rare in the secular literature does not mean that the fossils are rare; Jack Horner said in the NG article that other dinosaurs are "probably similarly preserved," but workers in the field are usually reluctant to damage dinosaur bones to look inside (maybe partly because they don't expect to find soft tissue after millions of years). What this story illustrates is how scientists tend to find what they expect to find, look for what they need to find, and ask the questions prompted by their worldview. It's instructive to notice who was surprised by today's announcement.

Here's what I want: I want someone to please tell me exactly what evidence is there to suggest that dinosaurs are millions of years old?
Absolutely impossible to do in the limited space available on this board. That presumes that I am actually aware of all of the evidence, and I freely admit that I am not. But I can give you a start. First, check out this picture. This is a picture of the K-T boundary that has been exposed in a hillside by erosion. This picture is from Alberta, Canada, but it isn't far from where I grew up and where I studied biology. There are many hills in my home state like this. The K-T boundary is that black layer. It is identifiable around the world and everywhere that it has become visible because of erosion, it can be easily dated by a variety of dating methods. It always dates to 65 million years (one of those methods is not carbon 14). Anywhere a fossil of a dinosaur has been found, it has been in strata below the K-T boundary. There has never been found a single exception (except for birds, that are descended from theropod dinosaurs).

It seems that ss was duped once more by creationists. He seems unaware of the fact that the reason that Dr. Schweitzer made the statement in which she denied finding blood or bloody tissue was that creationists had already misrepresented the results reported in her paper. She did not report that this is tissue from the original organism. That is still being investigated as far as I know. However, similar results have been obtained from a total of 4 specimens.
 
 What was reported was the presence of flexible bifurcating vessels, similar to blood vessels, elastic tissue-like material that resembles bone matrix, and heme compounds that are concentrated in structures similar to blood cells. No blood was found. Heme is the iron compound in hemoglobin.
 
 It will be interesting if it is determined that the material extracted from the bones actually contains material from the organism or if this is some unknown process that occurs during fossilization. If it is original material, then it will be protein, and from that, something of the DNA can be deduced. Nevertheless, this material would not be an appropriate sample for C-14 dating. Even if any were found, it would be an indication of contamination or an indication that this is not original organic material.

You're kidding, right? Scientists have no idea what killed the dinosaurs. The asteroid theory is nothing but a wild guess. There certainly is not a concensous that dinosaurs died this way -- and certainly no proof.

 You lie. Scientists have little doubt what killed the dinosaurs. Not only is there an iridium layer at the K-T boundary, but a giant crater off the Yucatan was formed at the same time. Iridium is pretty rare on earth but is abundant in meteoroids. This is not a "wild guess"; it is putting two and two together (not that that's the extent of the evidence). I wouldn't be surprised, however, if you saw little difference between wild guesses and kindergarten arithmetic.
 
 
I can show you dinosaur bones that were laying on top of the ground -- what are you talking about ?

 What are you talking about? Do you simply enjoy flaunting your ignorance of geology? Were these fossils (not bones) found in rock younger than the K-T boundary, like obvious_child said they wouldn't be? Of course they weren't. You're full of XXXX.
 
 
Why don't you date the bones instead of the sand/soil/rock/dirt that's around the bones?

 Which radioactive isotopes with appropriate half-lives exist in the fossils in sufficient quantities to facilitate measurement?
 
 
Besides, what "strata" would the dinosaur be in here:

 How could I possibly tell from either that picture or that text, or even both combined? How about you ask someone who knows anything about that particular specimen instead of asking someone for specified knowledge? This is like if I sent you a close-up picture of an interior wall and asked how many walls are between it and outside.
 
 
And what do you think....did they date the sand above, below, and inside the bones of the dinosaur so they can narrow down when the dinosaur lived?

 Sedimentary rock isn't tested (nor is loose sediment); any results would be based on the solidification of the igneous matter from which it came, and even that might be inaccurate due to opening of the system. When possible, extrusive igneous layers above and below the fossil are dated to give a maximum range.
 
 
I mean you do believe in uniformatarianism, right?....just a small, microscopic layer of sediment gets laid down every every thousand years or so?

 And you say this right after I explain that your only objections are either (1) reasonable claims that pose problems only for your misunderstanding of science or (2) inane claims period. Uniformitarianism is not the doctrine that a microscopic layer of sediment gets laid down every thousand years or so. The only people who claim it is are the scientifically illiterate who read too many crackpot fundy websites.
supersport

[B] obvious_child; 
 
 Now you're just lying. It's called erosion. Every land owner knows what it is. Why it is we have yet to find a single fossil above the iridium layer. You would argue that fresh organic material is just as old as a 3 billion year old rock that was unearthed after catashprohic climax changes merely because they were both found on top of the ground. No one everyone here considers you a idiot.
 
 You know....why is it that you people must resort to calling people liars? It just highlights the scumbag that you are.
 
 http://www.christiananswers.net/dinosaurs/alaska/trip-jul18.html
 
 The Liscomb bone bed has produced the most important dinosaur remains from Alaska. We collected bones on and below the surface. We found both fossilized and unfossilized bones. We dug down about three feet to get to the bones frozen in permafrost. It was the frozen unfossilized bones we were seeking for our research, although we collected some fossilized bones as well. 
 
 So what strata is "ON" the ground???????
 
 
 And about how the dinosaurs died? Scientists are indeed clueless and divided -- just like I said.
 
 http://filebox.vt.edu/artsci/geology/mclean/Dinosaur_Volcano_Extinction/pages/studentv.html
 
 The cause of the K-T extinctions is one of the great mysteries in science, and scientists have proposed many kinds of theories to account for it. They range from asteroid or comet impacts, volcanism, sea level changes, supernova explosions, and on and on. Beginning in the 1980s, two theories became the topic of intense scientific debate. These are: (1) the K-T impact extinction theory originated by the Nobel physicist, Luis Alvarez, and his team, and (2) the K-T Deccan Traps volcanism-induced carbon cycle perturbation extinction theory originated by the author which, for short, I call the volcano-greenhouse theory. 
 
 He doesn't sound as confident as you.
 
 
 Neither do these people....in fact, they're still looking for the for "the big hit."
 
 http://www.planetark.com/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/24072/story.htm
 
 Now they need to find the actual crater left by whatever made this final blow. Perhaps one known as the Shiva crater in India, dating to around the same period, is the one, they suggested.
 
 Yea -- all they need now is evidence. 
 
 Boy science sucks. What a freaking joke.

You know....why is it that you people must resort to calling people liars? It just highlights the scumbag that you are.

 
 Either you are incredibly stupid or you are a liar.
 
 
So what strata is "ON" the ground???????

 
 Do you even understand what the Iridium layer is?
 
 I asked you a simple question. your website does not even discuss the iridium layer.

 That's quite funny comming from you. The K-T Deccan Traps volcanism-induced carbon cycle perturbation extinction theory is not taught or even considered to be of serious scientific value nor does it conicide with the iridium layer and the lack of fossils found above the layer. He doesn't sound as confident as you.

 
 His ideas are not taught as factual. 
 
 

 Neither do these people....in fact, they're still looking for the for "the big hit."

 
 No, they are trying to prove which of the craters acutally did it. 
 
 You haven't answered a single one of my questions. Nor do you show the basic understanding of what I'm asking either.

 Let's just ignore that science is the reason most of us exist today. 
 
 But what is more of a joke is that you bought hook line and sinker the commercial art of villagers as proof of creation.

 Because you lie. Your entire post ignores my previous post. You say scientists are clueless about the K-T extinction and that uniformitarianism requires strict gradualism.
